title: Explore data in the Global Coal Plant Tracker
footer: All data comes from GEM's [Global Coal Plant Tracker](https://globalenergymonitor.org/projects/global-coal-plant-tracker/), last updated in January 2025. Units on this page are in gigawatts (GW). Operating includes mothballed capacity. Under development includes all capacity with status announced, pre-permit, permitted, and construction.

dropdown.overall_summary: Global operating coal power capacity has increased 13% since 2015.
Operating coal power capacity in BRICS countries/areas has increased 30% since 2015.

Operating coal power capacity in the 27 member states of the European Union (EU27) has fallen 36% since 2015.
Only a single coal-fired power station, in Poland, remains in development.

The Group of Seven major industrial countries (G7) account for 13% of the world’s operating coal capacity, down from 23% in 2015.
The G7 no longer has any coal in construction, but is still home to one proposal in Japan and two in the United States.
The Group of Twenty (G20) is home to 93% of the world’s operating coal power capacity and 92% of coal power capacity under development.

Operating coal power capacity in countries part of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has fallen 27% since 2015.
Only four countries in the OECD – Australia, Japan, Türkiye, and the United States – are still considering new coal projects.
Albania has no operating coal plants. It also has no coal power under development.
